questions.question: Question 1: Pharmacovigilance refers to:

options.b: Monitoring of unethical trade of drugs

questions.explanation:
Pharmacovigilance deals with the monitoring of drug safety. WHO definition of pharmacovigilance: "Science and activities related to the detection, assessment, understanding, and prevention of 
adverse effects or any other drug-related problems”.

questions.question:
Question 2: Which of the following organizations regulates the clinical trials and approval of 
investigational new drugs in India?
questions.explanation:
Central Drug Standard Control Organisation (CDSCO) regulates the clinical trials and approval of 
investigational new drugs in India. The proposal for initiating trials, review of clinical trial results, and recommendations for 
marketing authorization is done through a committee called the Investigational New Drug (IND) 
Committee formed by CDSCO. Preclinical trials are performed on animals, and they are regulated by guidelines prescribed by 
the Committee for the Purpose of the Control and Supervision of Experiments on Animals 
(CPCSEA) in India. The Drugs Controller General of India (DCGI) is the head of the CDSCO, under the Ministry of 
Health and Family Welfare in India.

questions.question:
Question 3: You are working as a research associate on clinical trials of a new drug for migraine. What is 
the dose of the test drug that is usually not exceeded in phase 0 studies?
questions.explanation:
The dose of the test drug in phase 0 studies usually does not exceed 100mcg. Phase 0 studies are 
also called micro-dosing studies. Very low doses of drugs, usually 1/100th of the estimated human dose or a maximum of 100 mcg 
is used. They are done to obtain pharmacokinetic data in humans at a very early stage of drug 
development. The micro-dosing stage is not mandatory and not clearly categorized by regulatory 
authorities yet. 58 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: Good clinical practice is not required in which phase of clinical trials?
questions.explanation:
Good clinical practice is not required in the preclinical phase. Good clinical practice (GCP) is an international ethical and scientific quality standard for the 
design, conduct, performance, monitoring, auditing, recording, analyses, and reporting of clinical 
trials. It is primarily for the conduct of clinical trials in humans. Preclinical trials are performed on animals and they are regulated by guidelines prescribed 
by the CPCSEA (Committee for the Purpose of the Control and Supervision of Experiments on 
Animals) in India. The guidelines are laid down in good laboratory practice (GLP).

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is not a primary endpoint in phase 1 studies?
questions.explanation:
Efficacy is not a primary endpoint in phase 1 studies. Phase 1 studies are generally done in healthy 
volunteers. Efficacy can be a secondary endpoint in some studies where patients are recruited. The primary endpoints are: • Safety • Tolerability of single/multiple doses • Pharmacokinetic parameters The primary endpoint denotes the purpose of the study for which it is primarily designed. The 
secondary endpoint denotes the measure of the valuable outcome of the study design.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following phases of a clinical trial is also referred to as efficacy trial?
questions.explanation:
Efficacy and appropriate dose range is the main aim of phase 2 of clinical trials. It is evaluated on 
a small group of patients with the target disease. Phase II of clinical trials involve a small group of patients (50-500). Most of the new drugs will be 
administered for the first time in patients with the target disease. The study is designed to obtain 
proof of concept (potential of the drug to treat the disease) and dose-ranging study (provides input 
for choosing the most appropriate dose for phase 3 studies). Phase 3 studies are also known as pivotal studies as they establish treatment benefits.

questions.question:
Question 7: You read a news alert that mentions a novel drug has received marketing approval for 
diabetes mellitus and that it has shown positive results in a pivotal trial. This corresponds to 
which phase of clinical trials?
questions.explanation:
Phase III trials are usually considered pivotal trials and are necessary for the approval of the 
majority of drugs. They are also called multi-site trials and are done for 3–5 years. 59 
Sold by @itachibot When the initial Phase III trials are complete, the sponsor (usually a pharmaceutical company) 
applies to the FDA for approval to market the drug. This application is called either a New Drug 
Application (NDA) or a Biologics License Application (BLA). In some drugs related to rare diseases or malignancies, phase II studies are considered as pivotal, 
and the drug may be approved on the basis of phase II studies.

questions.question:
Question 8: A pharmaceutical company has set up a team of physicians to oversee the Phase IV clinical 
trial of a new drug for SARS-CoV2 infection, to identify possible drug interactions. Which is 
the most appropriate statement about this phase of the clinical trial? 52 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Done in a group of 50-500 patients
options.b: Done after a drug is approved and marketed
options.c: Done for drugs used in rare diseases
options.d: Done for formulating guidelines for therapeutic use

questions.explanation:
Phase IV study is conducted after the drug is approved and marketed by regulatory authorities. It 
includes post-marketing surveillance and other studies that complement the earlier findings of the 
drug. After the drug is marketed for general use, practicing physicians are identified through whom 
data about the efficacy, acceptability, and adverse effects of the drug are collected on a structured 
proforma. Patients treated in the normal course form the study population. Therefore the study 
population is much larger. Uncommon adverse effects or those that occur only after long-term use 
and unsuspected drug interactions are detected at this stage.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following statements are true?
questions.explanation:
Orphan drugs are for the treatment or prevention of rare diseases with little commercial value for 
pharmaceutical companies. Orphan receptors are receptors that are discovered yet no known 
ligands are identified. There are two types of drug development. They are: • Traditional drug development: Initial drug discovery is followed by the characterization of the 
receptors the drugs are used to act on. • Contemporary drug development: Due to advances in molecular biology and genome 
sequencing, receptors are identified initially. The drugs are identified later using chemical 
screening later resulting in the discovery of orphan receptors. Special incentives are given by the government to pharmaceutical companies for the development 
and marketing of orphan drugs. Few examples of orphan drugs are: • Liposomal amphotericin B • Digoxin antibody (Digibind) • Fomepizole

questions.question:
Question 10: A pharmacologically inert substance used along with an active ingredient in a formulation is 
known as the:
questions.explanation:
60 
Sold by @itachibot An excipient is a pharmacologically inert substance used along with an active ingredient in a 
formulation. e.g., starch, lactose, FDKP Role of excipients: • Add bulk to the active drug if used in small quantities • Increase the stability of the formulation • Mask unpleasant taste Inhaled insulin (Afrezza) consists of 2- to 2.5-m crystals of the excipient, fumaryl 
diketopiperazine (FDKP), that provides a large surface area for adsorption of proteins like 
insulin. Option A: Placebo is an inert substance given in the form of medication. It is generally not 
combined with the active ingredient. • Endorphins may play a role in the placebo effect especially for analgesic action. • It is used in the controls of clinical trials to elucidate the actual drug effect. • Not all but only a few patients respond to the placebo. Option B: Nocebo is the opposite of the placebo effect where the patient experiences a negative 
psychodynamic effect due to their pessimistic attitude towards the medications or healthcare 
professionals. Option C: Inducers refer to agents that increase the expression of cytochrome enzymes involved in 
the metabolism of drugs.

questions.question: Question 11: Which one of the following is a placebo?

options.a: Herbal medication with no effect known

questions.explanation:
Sham surgery (placebo surgery) is a faked surgical intervention that omits the step thought to be 
therapeutically necessary. Note: While option A may be considered a placebo due to there being no known effects, it is not 
certain as to whether all possible effects (known and unknown) have been considered. Hence, 
weighing options A and C, the better option among the two would be C as sham surgery is a 
widely used placebo.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following are not reasons for the alteration of drug dosage in the elderly? 53 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: They have decreasing renal function with age
options.b: They have loss of lean body mass
options.d: Their total body water is decreased

questions.explanation:
The reason for the alteration of drug dosage in the elderly is decreased baroreceptor sensitivity 
due to age-related vascular stiffening. Reasons for the alteration of drug dosage in the elderly are: • Progressive decline of renal function • Loss of lean body mass and an increased ratio of fat to muscle, leading to an increased volume of 
distribution of lipophilic drugs • Decreased body water - causing volume of distribution (Vd) of hydrophilic drugs decreases. 61 
Sold by @itachibot • Slower absorption due to reduced gut motility. • Plasma albumin decreases with aging which leads to decreased plasma protein binding.

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient started on an anti-epileptic for epilepsy developed toxic epidermal necrolysis. It was 
documented as a type A adverse drug reaction. Which of the following is not true regarding 
this adverse effect?

options.a: These reactions occur due to genetically determined abnormal reactivity to a drug.
options.b: These reactions can be predicted from the drug’s known pharmacological or toxicological

questions.explanation:
Type A (augmented) adverse drug reactions (ADR) are not based upon the qualitatively abnormal 
responses to the drug. It is based on the pharmacological properties of the drug. Examples of type A ADR: • Side effects • Toxic effects • Consequences of drug withdrawal. They are common, reversible, and preventable. Idiosyncrasy refers to the genetically determined abnormal reactivity to a drug. Adverse drug reactions can be classified into two types: • Type A reactions – sometimes referred to as augmented reactions – are dose-dependent and 
predictable based on the pharmacology of the drug • Type B reactions – bizarre reactions – which are idiosyncratic and not predictable on the basis of 
drug pharmacology. They can be based on the characteristics of patients.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following drugs if taken during pregnancy can lead to this adverse effect?
questions.explanation:
The baby has features suggestive of phocomelia and it results due to the consumption of 
thalidomide during pregnancy. Phocomelia is associated with underdeveloped limbs and absent pelvic bones. Both upper and 
lower limbs are affected and a part of the limbs may be missing. Fused fingers and missing 
thumbs are also seen. Thalidomide was originally used for the treatment of pregnancy-associated morning sickness but 
was withdrawn due to this adverse effect. It re-entered the market for the treatment of erythema nodosum leprosum. It also 
has antiangiogenic and immunomodulatory effects.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following drugs can be used in the first trimester of pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
62

questions.question:
Question 16: Which of the following drugs cannot cross the placenta and can safely be used in a pregnant 
woman?
questions.explanation:
Heparin is a large molecule and cannot cross the placenta. Hence, heparin can be used safely in a 
pregnant woman. Unfractionated or low molecular weight heparin is the preferred anticoagulant in pregnancy. Option A: Phenytoin crosses the placenta and can cause fetal hydantoin syndrome. Options B and C: Diazepam and morphine are lipophilic molecules and can cross the placenta.

questions.question:
Question 17: 'Me-too drugs' do not differ significantly in which of the following pharmacological features as 
compared to the prototypical drug?
questions.explanation:
Me-too drugs are chemically related to the prototype or other chemical compounds that have an 
identical mechanism of action. Various statins present in the market can be considered as "Me-too drugs". The pharmacokinetic 
parameters (absorption, distribution, metabolism, and elimination) vary significantly between 
them (atorvastatin and rosuvastatin have a very long duration of action), but the core mechanism 
of action remains the same: HMG CoA reductase inhibition and decrease in cholesterol synthesis.

questions.question:
Question 18: As a medical officer in a PHC, you anticipate a rise in infections following the worsening flood 
in your area. You write a letter to the district collector requesting to provide an additional 
supply of essential medicines. Which of the following best describes these medicines?

options.a: These are drugs needed to treat emergency conditions
options.b: These are drugs needed to treat serious diseases
options.c: These are drugs that satisfy the priority health needs of the population
options.d: These are drugs that have been in use for a long time

questions.explanation:
Essential medicines are those medicines that satisfy the priority health care needs of the 
population. They are selected with due regard to: • Public health relevance • Evidence on efficacy and safety • Comparative cost-effectiveness WHO publishes a model list of essential medicines that provides a framework for individual 
nations to draw their own national list. The 21st Essential Medicines List, published in April 2019 
brings the total to 460 drugs deemed essential for addressing the most important public health 
needs globally.

questions.question:
Question 19: The schedule that deals with prescription drugs under the Drugs and Cosmetics Act is 
 
.
questions.explanation:
Schedule H deals with prescription drugs. All the drugs listed under schedule H should be 
provided to the patient only with the prescription from a registered medical practitioner. 63 
Sold by @itachibot All the drugs under the list must have the warning mentioned below, on their packaging listed 
prominently. "Schedule H drug. Warning: To be sold by retail on the prescription of a registered medical 
practitioner only" Schedule H1: To be sold on the production of a valid prescription, but the chemist will maintain a 
separate register where the identity of the patient, contact details of the prescribing doctor, and 
the name and dispensed quantity of the drug will be recorded. The dispensing quantity should be 
strictly according to the valid prescription. It is a recently introduced list with the objective of 
curtailing indiscriminate use of antimicrobials. Schedule X: To be sold with a valid prescription. Prescription in duplicate, separate license 
requirements, meticulous storage, and dispensing records must be maintained by the chemist. 
The drugs that have high abuse liability are included in schedule X.

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following is a schedule X drug?
questions.explanation:
Ketamine is a schedule X drug. According to The Drugs and Cosmetics Act-1945, Schedule X drugs are those that have high abuse liability and are to be sold with a valid 
prescription only. A prescription in duplicate, separate license requirement, meticulous storage, and dispensing 
records must be maintained by the chemist. Option B: Thalidomide is a schedule H drug. Option D: Colistin is a schedule P drug.

questions.question:
Question 21: A first-year resident administers an intramuscular injection to a patient by the Z track 
technique. What is the advantage of this technique?
questions.explanation:
The advantage of the 'Z-track technique' for intramuscular administration is that it prevents skin 
staining. Z-track technique procedure: • Stretch the skin by pulling it laterally away from the intended point of injection. • Insert the needle into the site at a 90■ angle, aspirate by pulling back to see if the needle has a 
penetrated vessel. • If blood is aspirated withdraw the needle, and repeat the procedure at another site with new 
equipment and medication. • If no blood is aspirated administer the injection. • Wait for 10 seconds and then withdraw the needle, and release the skin allowing the displaced 
tissue to seal the needle track. Advantages: 64 
Sold by @itachibot • The 'Z-track' prevents leakage of the medication into the subcutaneous tissue and skin staining 
through the tract to the surface of the skin • Pain intensity is also reduced

questions.question:
Question 22: Z track technique is used for? 56 
Sold by @itachibot

options.c: Administration of long acting depot antipsychotics

questions.explanation:
The Z-track technique is used for the intramuscular administration of long-acting depot 
antipsychotics. Advantages: • The 'Z-track' prevents leakage of the medication into the subcutaneous tissue and skin 
staining through the tract to the surface of the skin • Pain intensity is also reduced 65 
Sold by @itachibot
